quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 10 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 10.8: Gibbs Calculations
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Quantitative application of the Gibbs equation

questions.question: When using the equation $\Delta G = \Delta H - T\Delta S$, what is the most common unit conversion error?
options: Failing to convert $\Delta S$ from J/mol·K to kJ/mol·K.
Failing to convert Temperature from Kelvin to Celsius.
Multiplying the entire equation by the gas constant $R$.
Converting $\Delta H$ into Joules instead of kiloJoules.
questions.explanation: Enthalpy is usually given in $kJ/mol$ while Entropy is in $J/mol\cdot K$. You must divide the entropy term by 1000 to ensure the units match.

questions.question: Calculate $\Delta G^{\circ}$ for a reaction at 298 K where $\Delta H^{\circ} = -95.0\ kJ/mol$ and $\Delta S^{\circ} = -120\ J/mol\cdot K$.
To find the temperature at which a reaction reaches equilibrium or changes spontaneity, which condition is set?
questions.explanation: Equilibrium is the point where the forward and backward reactions are equally favorable, meaning the net change in free energy is zero.

questions.question: If $\Delta H = +125\ kJ/mol$ and $\Delta S = +350\ J/mol\cdot K$, at what temperature does the reaction become spontaneous?
questions.explanation: $T = \Delta H / \Delta S = 125000 / 350 \approx 357.1\ K$. Since $\Delta S$ is positive, higher temperatures favor spontaneity.

questions.question: Calculate $\Delta G^{\circ}_{rxn}$ using the following values: $\Delta G_{f}^{\circ}[NO_{2}] = 51.3\ kJ/mol$, $\Delta G_{f}^{\circ}[N_{2}O_{4}] = 97.8\ kJ/mol$ for the reaction: $2NO_{2}(g) \rightarrow N_{2}O_{4}(g)$.
What is the $\Delta S$ of a system if $\Delta G = -20\ kJ/mol$, $\Delta H = -50\ kJ/mol$, and $T = 300\ K$?
questions.explanation: Rearranging $\Delta G = \Delta H - T\Delta S \rightarrow \Delta S = (\Delta H - \Delta G) / T$. $\Delta S = (-50 - (-20)) / 300 = -30 / 300 = -0.1\ kJ/mol\cdot K = -100\ J/mol\cdot K$.

questions.question: A reaction has $\Delta G^{\circ} = -10.0\ kJ/mol$ at 298 K. If the temperature is increased to 500 K and $\Delta S^{\circ}$ is $+50\ J/mol\cdot K$, what is the new $\Delta G^{\circ}$ (assuming $\Delta H$ and $\Delta S$ are constant)?
questions.explanation: First find $\Delta H$ at 298K: $-10 = \Delta H - (298 \times 0.050) \rightarrow \Delta H = 4.9\ kJ$. Then at 500K: $\Delta G = 4.9 - (500 \times 0.050) = 4.9 - 25 = -20.1\ kJ$.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct Gibbs-Helmholtz related calculation for $\Delta S_{surroundings}$?
questions.explanation: The entropy change of the surroundings is directly proportional to the heat released by the system and inversely proportional to the temperature.

questions.question: The boiling point of a liquid can be estimated using the values of $\Delta H_{vap}$ and $\Delta S_{vap}$ because at the boiling point:
options: Liquid and gas are in equilibrium, so $\Delta G = 0$.
The entropy of the liquid is zero.
The enthalpy of vaporization is zero.
questions.explanation: At any phase transition temperature, the two phases coexist in equilibrium, making the free energy change for the transition zero ($T_{bp} = \Delta H_{vap} / \Delta S_{vap}$).

questions.question: In a calculation where $\Delta G$ is very close to zero, what can be concluded about the reaction?
options: The reaction is at or near equilibrium.
The reaction is only possible in a vacuum.
questions.explanation: A $\Delta G$ of zero (or nearly zero) signifies a system that has no net drive to change in either the forward or reverse direction.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You handled the unit conversions and algebraic rearrangements perfectly.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Watch out for the Joules to kiloJoules conversion.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Practice rearranging the Gibbs equation for T and S.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the basic calculation: $\Delta G = \Delta H - T\Delta S$.
